title: Manchester United goal was right to stand, claims ex-referee Dermot Gallagher
text:
Liverpool were incensed by the decision to allow the goal (Picture: Getty)

The refereeing team at Manchester United vs Liverpool were right to allow Marcus Rashford’s opener to stand, according to Dermot Gallagher.

Rashford gave United, who were 4/1 underdogs coming into the game, a 1-0 lead after 36 minutes at Old Trafford.

The goal was checked by the Video Assistant Referee (VAR) who infuriated Liverpool fans by refusing to intervene on a challenge by Victor Lindelof on Divock Origi, after which United won the ball and broke away to score.

Replays appeared to show the defender catch Origi on the back of the calf but Gallagher, who spent 15 years as a Premier League referee, has insisted that not awarding a free-kick was a subjective decision and therefore one which the VAR could not overrule.

Origi was left holding his left leg after what he felt was a foul (Picture: Getty)

‘It is not a VAR decision. It is Martin Atkinson’s decision,’ Gallagher told Sky Sports.

‘The referee is the closest person to it and he says no.

‘There was a debate this morning, 50,000 people voted [on a Sky Twitter poll] and half say yes, half say no.

‘So for the VAR, it’s not clear and obvious and it cannot go against the referee.’

Gallagher did concede that he felt that Lindelof’s challenge was worthy of a free-kick, but that the correct protocol was followed afterwards.

‘I did think it was a foul. He has the best view and he waved it away, he said no,’ Gallagher added.

‘Once he does that, it is out of the VAR’s hands because it’s such a subjective decision. So they can’t go with it.

‘[The VAR] did check it but the feeling was that the referee had the best view and he didn’t feel it was a foul.

Liverpool players protested to Atkinson after the goal but to no avail (Picture: Getty)

‘He thought it was contact but not enough to give a foul.

‘The referee was close and said no foul straight away.

This is a referee’s decision on the field.’
description: The refereeing team at Manchester United vs Liverpool were right to allow Marcus Rashford's opener to stand, according to Dermot Gallagher.
